subject: Re: Testing Private Methods
msgSnippet: ... Sorry if it came across that way.  That wasn t the intent.  I have some strong ideas about TDD. Granted this isn t the TDD list, it s the JUnit list.. I
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Colbert <mbcolbert@y...>"
<mbcolbert@y...> wrote:
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Bill de h√ìra <dehora@e...> wrote:
> > To me Mike, you're coming across as rude.
>
> I'm curious, do you find this rude?
> http://groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/6415
>
> To me, it smacks of self-righteousness and shameless self-promotion.

Sorry if it came across that way. That wasn't the intent. I have
some strong ideas about TDD.

Granted this isn't the TDD list, it's the JUnit list.. I guess I
sometimes loose site of the fact that a lot of people using JUnit
don't do TDD. Different techniques apply. My point of view is from
the practice of pure TDD. As I've been accused of before, I am a bit
of a purist about some things. I don't expect it to be applicable to
everyone, or every project.

> I didn't come here to have some guy and his buddy disparage the ideas
> that I offer without offering anything in exchange other than, "This
> is how it is. Buy my book!"

But it or don't, I don't really care. I wrote it because I saw a
need, and had something to say that I felt other people might be
interested in hearing.

FYI I've gotten some very good feedback on the book.

> I think if a person jumps into a discussion and says, "Your approach
> sucks. Buy my book!"

That's not quite what I said.

> > Yet, I haven't
> > seen any explanation as to what is inferior in your approach -
> > asserting it's inferior does not make it so.
>
> I couldn't agree more.

The main thing is "does it work for you?"

If so, great. But could it work better? I talk about what I've
proven works well for me.

> For the record, I never said I disagreed with what Dave and J. B.
> are advocating. I never said I didn't like them personally, either.
> It's the delivery of their message I find curious.

Young children tend to be frightened by me as well... until they get
to know me, that is.

> It seems more geared toward self-interest than equitable exchange
> or mutual benefit.

Well, it certainly stirred up some exchange.

Dave
